We are taking the next question comes from Mr. Pierre Chedeville from Crédit Mutuel Securities. You have the floor.

Yes. Good afternoon. Three quick questions. First question regarding consumer financing business, you focused on the increased cost of risk due to development in emerging markets. Could you give us any indication regarding what's the principal of the increase of the net margin which normally is symmetrical to these higher costs of risk, and what is the level of this net margin in these activities, I don't know, if it's increased? That's my first question.

My second question is you have doubtful loan coverage of 60%, which is quite stable since 2007. Do you feel comfortable with the stability of this coverage, due to the current situation and due to – it's hard what we can imagine, but we will now experience a degeneration of the economic climate at the worldwide basis? And my last question would be, how would you qualify the coming periods of the banking industry? Do you thing what we are entering after the subprime crisis to a more classical crisis, banking, more classical banking crisis, or do you think that we are entering a normal time?

Yeah. Good afternoon. Regarding your question on the cost of risk and margins in the – at emerging markets in consumer finance. Well, you have an illustration of that on slide 14, where you can see productivity, and provisions are based into total revenues, and which is 100% considered on average. Provisions represent approximately 20 to 25% of the revenue generation of each country, which as you know is a little bit more important, but we believe that the normalization will take place as we let's say moving to the model a bit more to cap financing for the recent acquisition of – from Edge, and to less extent at KP. We are seeing exactly the same movements in terms of margins, let's say, if we have to look at the margin increase on the total of spending, we have seen for example 100 bps increase overall for the SG Consumer Finance division, which is coming mainly from which have double digit figure in terms of net spread.

Regarding your second question on the nonperforming loans and their coverage, we feel comfortable with such coverage. Having in mind that also on the ratio that you can calculate from appendices, you do not include the portfolio based provisions which also are reporting in the accounts in the balance sheet for appropriately 1 billion. Revisions are more than that. So this is also increasing the coverage. You could calculate mechanically. Regarding the going forward evolution of the banking sector, I will let Frédéric answer.

Yeah, I mean, again I think the environment first of all remains relatively uncertain. And the crisis we are facing with different ingredients, this crisis of real estate market in certain economies; the liquidity crisis, there is more liquidity today, but nevertheless the cost of liquidity remains relatively high. The inflation related to the oil price, and the agricultural commodities. These ingredients, if you wish, added together means a cocktail that has not been experienced in the past.

So I think we need to remain cautious. The central scenario that our economists have in mind for the next 18 months is a slowdown of the activity in the U.S. and in Continental Europe. As I said, potentially you can translate that at the end of 2008 and beginning of 2009, and for example, they have in mind for the U.S. this year a growth of 1.6% and 0.7% next year; and 1.5% for the euro zone and 1% for next year.

And potentially, with a pick up – sorry, 0.5 for next year for the U.S. And so, if you wish, with a pick up potentially of the GDP growth in the second half for overseas improvement, if you wish, in the second half of 2009.

I don't think that this kind of environment could be considered as a normal environment. If you wish, we are far from the group potential from the different countries. It means that you might see effectively – so you might see again further deterioration on certain sectors for example in the real estate market in the U.S. or in the U.K. in our view, and again with certain elements of uncertainly like the evolution of credit for example in the U.S.

Overall, when I look at the exposure of our bank, again, we are in, you can sense, in Europe exposed to France, and I would say that the French economy should be at the end of the day probably a bit more resilient than other economies. The outlook for growth in the U.K., Spain or Italy is not strong, and more importantly on the housing market and mortgage market, as you know, the origination process has remained sound.

And with the banking sector overall, I think, we should fare relatively well with the crisis. So again that's our major exposure in Continental Europe. We are not exposed to the retail in the U.S., and as I've said, resilient market. And we are exposed in emerging markets where we can expect some slowdown also. And we don't believe in the decoupling if you wish of these economies, the emerging market economies through the western world, but nevertheless, overall countries which should do well, we have a spread of countries with economies which are not correlated with each other. What I mean by that, we have different economies, some of them with the benefit of strong commodity results, and overall, I would say compared with other countries, I think we are exposed to good countries in relative terms.

So I think we need to remain cautious. 2008 will remain for Société Générale a year during which we will try to capitalize on our franchises, enhance our capital ratios, to take opportunities in 2009. I have the conviction that in this market there will be also a lot of opportunities, and again I would like us to be able to seize these opportunities.
Thank you.
Do we have further questions?

Well, if not, I would like to thank you for the attention during this conf call. Of course, I wish you all the best for these 30 days that certainly will start for most of you, you have some work I know tomorrow. And again, thank you for your attention. Bye-bye.
Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the Société Générale's conference call. Thank you all for attending. You may now disconnect.
